class.classNotes: This type plays both the part of an adjective and an adverb. In Lodenkur, there is no distinction.
Not a standalone word, but a modifier to be fixed to the front of words.
Technically all prepositions are adjectivals, but they are never separated from their trailing "si", and otherwise treated as locative elements.

word.definition: On Darisa, a standard week is 5 days.
At all times. At every occurance.
Clothing.
Book.
To receive or get.
Wet. Not dry.
To say. This is the word used to quote someone.
Gender neutral, singular word to refer to someone other than yourself, or the person you are speaking to. Implies that the subject of the word is of equal importance and/or age to the speaker.
Gender neutral, singular word to refer to someone other than yourself, or the person you are speaking to. Implies that the subject of the word is of greater importance and/or age than the speaker.
Gender neutral, singular word to refer to someone other than yourself, or the person you are speaking to. Implies that the subject of the word is of lesser importance and/or age to the speaker.
Used when referencing the person to whom you are currently speaking. Inherently singular.
Day, specifically describing the time of day, rather than a whole revolution of the planet.
Lunch.Lit: day meal
I, me, or myself.
Night.
Dinner.Lit: night meal
To swim.
Name.
Water.
Round.
Approximate, roughly, or about.
A state in the sense of government.
To sleep.
To describe.
Meal.
1) The flesh of an animal.2 The edible portion of a fruit.
To cook.

This can be afixed to the beginning of words to make them conceptually larger. Care must be taken, as some words have their meaning fundamentally changed by the prefix. For example, a "big sit" is lying down.
The closest thing to "year" in Lodenkur, the "great week" is 25 weeks.
Outer space.Lit: great sky
Mountain.Lit: great rock
To lie down, or to be lying down.Lit: "big sit"
Once again, or repetitious.
A large single dimension. Can be applied to time, or other concepts.
"We," or "us."This is technically the plural form of "I."
Sand
A party, or celebration.
This word is used exclusively as an ennumerative conjuction, rather than one which binds phrases together (for which there is another word).
One of two or more possibilities.
Soup.
To put together to increase overall size.
frightened, afraidLiterally, all-dark.
Filled up; full.
Cloud.
Smoke.
The sky.
Anything visibly orbiting a planet. Includes both moons of Darisa, Dod and Kur'dod, artificial satalites that twinkle, and the natural satalites of other planets in their solar system.
Rain.
Town.
Bad.
1) Animal blood.2) A plant's sap or ichor.
To consume a liquid.
To kill.
Holy or divine.
A storage chest.
All. This may be used to imply plurality ("I" becomes "we" when modified by this), or in the sense of completeness, such as "All dressed in white."
A neighbor. Can apply to anyone living very close to the speaker.
A ward. Specifically, the relationship that one takes after being sired by another into a new life.
The ground, or floor. The surface on which you are standing.
Establishes a relationship between two things, the first in some way encompasing the second, whether through a grouped inclusion, direct ownership, or some more abstract sense of belonging.
plantAny life falling within a related set of organisms on Ki'
An animal's head. May also be used to refer to "head" in a more abstract way, such as leaders, or the frontmost element of a list/line.
Stone. May refer to either the material, or a singular chunk of it.
1) The attribute associated with an object being affected by gravity.2) An object being used due to its heaviness.
Nouse or sound.
Without light. May refer both to the shade of a color, or the level of light in an area.
To give.
Mouth. Used primarily to describe the mouths of animals, but can refer to any opening which things primarily pass into.
Lonely.
RootRefers specifically to plant roots, but is very commonly used metaphorically, as in "A word's root."

1) New. In this context, the word has a positive connotation, implying that the subject has not yet been worn out.2) Young. In this context, the word has a negative connotation, implying that the subject is inexperienced and unready for something. If applied to a person, it refers to the entire extent of their lives, rather than to the age of their current body.
leaf, blade of grass, etc.Literally, "plant shard."
This describes a voice, as perceived by a kukun. This differs from a voice as imagined by a human, as kukun'lu communicate via low frequency radio, rather than audio signals.
Seed. This, much like in English, refers both to plant seeds and to the germ cells of animal reproduction.
Any larger plant with bark and a central trunk
Skin, the outer layer covering something.
To bite.
Fire, or flame.
To sit.
Something's upper portion.
Ash. Lit: fire dung
Something's lower portion.
Path.
Bone of an animal, or the material of an arthropod's shell (although not the shell itself)
To love.
Small in size, either physically or conceptually.
An explicitly unknow object or concept. Typically used in an interrogative sense.
Master. This applies, as in english, both to an individual who has mastered a skill, or the master of a slave.
In.
A creature's claw.
A rope.
The knee or elbow of a creature's leg or arm. Synonymous, as Kukun frequently walk on all fours.
A slave.
Morning.
Breakfast.Lit: morning meal
Noon time.
Antennae. This describes anything that emits radio signals. Most frequently used when refering to the dual antennae found on any kukun or most animal life.
To knowingly speak a falsehood.
Big, largeA large size, either physically or conceptually.
To hear.
To consume a solid.
A card.
Species falling within a grouping on Ki'Darisa that is reasonably similar to what we call "birds."
Species falling within a grouping on Ki'Darisa that is reasonably similar to what we call "fish."
To burn.
A creature's tongue.
To die.
Animal.This is technically the gerrund (stem) form of the verb "to die."
The sun, a white dwarf star, whose name is "Cikil."
Dry. Not wet.
Through.
The foremost paw of any creature with opposable thumbs.
To visually see something.
Much, a multitude of. Applied to objects, this means that there is a great amount (wether the objects are counted singularly, like rocks, or like sand).

The closest equivalent to this word in English is "to hear," but it does not apply to sound. The Kukun'lu speak through transmission and reception of radio frequencies, and this verb applies specifically to the related sense.
Refers to a specific object or concept close at hand, or nearby conceptually. The referenced object must be out of easy reach, but within visual sight for this word to be used.
Refers to a specific object or concept close at hand, or nearby conceptually.
To fight.

Refers to a specific object or concept far away physicallty or conceptually. The referenced object must both be out of easy reach and out of sight. Typically not within the same building or location as the speaker unless the location is especially large.
A creature's ear.
An eye.

A group of individual persons. Applies specifically to the Kukun'lu, the only technologically or culturally advanced race on Ki'Darisa.The grouping may refer to the entire race, similar to "humanity" referring to all humans, or to a particular group within the species.
A singular person. Applies specifically to the Kukun'lu, the only technologically or culturally advanced race on Ki'Darisa.
Good.
To become.
An creature's face. Used exclusively to refer to the portion of a body.
Taking place following some relative time. This word applies only to time, not to physical positions.
This word is used exclusively as a conjunction which binds sentence fragments together, rather than an ennumerator (which there is a separate word for).
A creature's fur.
A creature's horn.
Any sort of bug that bites, or causes physical discomfort. The word implies the possibility of infestation, or persistent bother.
To know.
Snout, nose, or muzzle.
In conflict or competition. Standing contrary either in a literal, or a figurative sense.
To allow. As in "I will allow this."
The neck of something. Can be used in a similar fashion to "head," in that it is a connector between a it and a body, even if this is in a relatively abstract sense.
Tooth or fang.
A creature's tail.
A spring or coil. Specifically something that can be compressed or wound to store mechanical energy.
who, whomA pronon referencing an explicitly unknown party. Typically interogative in nature.
A position that is above some relative location.
Having the ability to do something. "Able" as in "They are able to do perform a task."
"Thank you."
To come from some other location to a current location.
1) A creature's heart. 2) The core of a concept.
A creature's foot, or the lowest portion of a support structure.
Not, un, antiThis is an adjectival form that may be applied to nearly any concept or verb to make it take the opposite meaning. if applied to a phrase, the phrase takes the opposite meaning.
To behave in a particular way. This bears the implication that the manner of acting is disingenuous.
To stand upright. This specifically refers to standing errect on one's hind legs.
To stand on all fours. This applies only when standing on all four limbs, rather than only the hind legs.
The egg of an animal. An external ovum, whether fertilized or not.
This refers to the primary pillar of support for something. For a plant, this is the trunk, or stalk. For a creature, this is the torso/belly.

Dung, feces, or poop. May be used in reference to general waste created by animals, machines, etc. The smoke from a car's tailpipe could be referenced by this under the right context. Any waste product.
Grease, or fat. May be used to describe anything that is viscous, and that is used to burn or to lubricate. Also describes grime of an oily nature.

This can be afixed to the beginning of words to make them conceptually smaller. Care must be taken, as some words have their meaning fundamentally changed by the prefix. For example, a "small voice" means "star."
A star in the sky. Technically Cikil, the sun over Ki'Darisa, is a star as well, and the kukun'lu are aware of this, but the word is rarely used to describe their sun.Lit: small voice

declensionNode.declensionNotes: Autogenerated from pre-0.7.5 version of PolyGlot.
